journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Modelling and recognition of a driver’s starting intentions

contrib-group.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Mechanical Building, 800 Dong Chuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: daifeng5539@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: This paper explores the classification, modelling, and recognition of a driver’s starting intentions of a passenger car equipped with an automatic mechanical transmission or a dual-clutch transmission. A driver’s intentions can be affected by a number of sources such as the driver’s current control actions, his or her visual scanning behaviour, and the traffic environment. The control actions, such as acceleration actions, are used to infer the driver’s starting intentions. Basically, the driver kinesthetically senses the acceleration, but not the speed. Therefore, a dynamic model for the driveline is proposed according to engine test data and the general parameters of the vehicle in order to analyse the influences of the pedal opening, the first derivative of the pedal opening, and the second derivative of the pedal opening on the starting intentions. An orthogonal test design is applied to treat the variables and their combinations for the driver’s decision making during launching the vehicle. It is demonstrated by the numerical results that the sequences of the factors exert different effects on the starting intentions, but the effects of their interactions can be ignored. According to these factors, a hidden Markov model is used to model and recognize the starting intentions. The results show that the system is able to recognize the driver’s starting intentions accurately.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: With the emergence of the energy crisis and environmental pollution, cars with better fuel economy, manoeuvrability, and comfort have attracted more attention and have undergone more development. Because transmission has a great influence on the car’s total performance and, in particular, on the handling performance and the fuel economy, an automatic transmission has long been one of the main features that people want in their cars. An automatic transmission is usually an automatic mechanical transmission (AMT) or a dual-clutch transmission (DCT) using a common manual gearbox and clutch control through a microprocessor. The essential advantage is the outstanding handling performance, which means that the workload can be greatly reduced and that traffic safety can be ensured by imitating a skilled driver’s outstanding transmission techniques. Also an AMT and a DCT result in better fuel economy. The results show that cars with AMT technology can reduce the fuel cost by nearly 20 per cent compared with those with a hydraulic automatic transmission, and by 9 per cent compared with those with a mechanical transmission. In addition, an AMT and a DCT have high reliability and low maintenance cost. However, the general defects of an AMT and a DCT with the traditional gear position decision methods are that they are too sensitive to the state parameters and do not adapt to the various driving environments and different driver’s intentions. An AMT and a DCT produce many unnecessary shifts in complex driving situations. Drivers often feel uncomfortable when driving vehicles with an AMT or a DCT, because their intentions cannot be reflected correctly.

According to statistics, 80–90 per cent of road traffic accidents are caused by human factors, of which 70–80 per cent are caused by human error. National studies have also shown that the driver is the most important factor causing road traffic accidents. Therefore, it is of great practical significance to study how the AMT system correctly understands the intentions of the driver, assists the driver to complete driving tasks better, and improves driving behaviour.

At present, there are many ways to study recognition and prediction of driving intentions. An integrated driver model which was developed utilizing adaptive control of thought-rational cognitive architecture and which focuses on the component processes of control, monitoring, and decision making in a multi-lane highway environment has been described by Salvucci [1]. A mathematical description of the driving behaviour has been established and used for prediction by Pentland and Liu [2]. Graphical models, a hidden Markov model (HMM) and a coupled HMM, which were trained using experimental driving data over 1.25 h to create models of seven different driver manoeuvres (namely passing, changing lanes right and left, turning right and left, starting, and stopping), were studied by Oliver and Pentland [3] and showed that, on average, the predictive power of the models was possible up to 1 s before the manoeuvre starts to take place. Driver demand acceleration characteristics were discussed by Wang et al. [4], which showed that a driver’s intentions on a planar straight road could be classified into five relative styles and proved that a driving environment was equivalent to certain driver intentions and could be integrated to infer those intentions. An attempt to assess the classification accuracy using the dynamic Markov model in real driving situations was made by Miyazaki et al. [5], which described the tests by categorizing a driver’s intended actions of stopping and doing nothing. A simple simulation predicting driver behaviour attitudes and errors at different levels of complexity was considered by Amantini and Cacciabue [6]. A simulation environment for evaluation and optimization of driver models was introduced by Benderius et al. [7], which described an optimization framework based on stochastic optimization algorithms to infer driver model parameters. Simulators, test-track techniques, on-road experiments, field operational trials, and naturalistic methods were described by McLaughlin et al. [8] when measuring the driver behaviour and performance.

Numerous research studies have been published on the modelling and prediction of a driver’s passing and stopping intentions. In this paper, the research interest is focused on a driver’s starting intentions. The influences of the pedal opening, the first derivative of the pedal opening, and the second derivative of the pedal opening on the starting intentions of the driver of a passenger car equipped with an AMT or a DCT is examined on the basis of the dynamic modelling of the driveline system. An HMM is used to model and recognize the starting intentions.

sec.title: 2 Dynamic Modelling of the Driveline System
sec.p: Driving is a process of information exchange and control. One of the key information driver senses is the kinesthetic sense, which often effects general feeling. In fact, the real human kinesthetic organ is the vestibular organ of the inner ear.

The vestibular organ includes three parts: semicircular canals, the utricle, and the saccule. The latter two contain the otolith and the semicircular canal is the main rotating sensor. It is equivalent to an angular velocity sensor, which senses orthogonal rotation in three directions. The otolith is mainly composed of the utricle and saccule and is located at the bottom of semicircular canals. It senses linear acceleration [9]. The analysis results above show that basically the driver kinesthetically senses the acceleration but not the speed. Thus the acceleration reflects the driver’s starting intentions.

The vehicle driveline system is a continuous and complex quality system, and research is concentrated on the dynamic modelling of the engine, the clutch, and the general vehicle. The engine model is the key to the entire vehicle driveline formulation. The steady output torque from the quasi-static torque map of the throttle input and the engine speed by bilinear interpolation is shown in Fig. 1.
The steady state output torque of the engine can be treated as usual as a function of the engine speed ne and the throttle valve parameter β in the form
The engine dynamic equilibrium equation can be given as

The driving and driven plates of the clutch obey the Coulomb friction law. The clutch friction torque during slipping may be expressed in the form

The test results for load–displacement curves of the small end of the diaphragm springs are plotted in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Test results for the load–displacement curve of the small end of the diaphragm springs

sec.p: The coefficient of friction of two surfaces in contact but moving relative to one another has been discussed in many research papers. Most researchers have concluded that accurate calculation of the variation in the coefficient of friction with the temperature, the rubbing speed, and the contact pressure, or indeed with any other physical parameter is not yet possible. A technique by Heap [10] is applied and the variation in the dynamic friction coefficient μ may be described as

in which μ(P), μ(Q), and μ(V) are polynomials describing the variations in the coefficient of friction with the normal pressure, temperature, and velocity respectively. Each applies when the other two variables remain constant. μV, μQ, and μP are the normalized coefficients for the polynomials, and μ0 is the static coefficient of friction in the reference condition. These polynomials are of the form
Values of the coefficients obtained from reference [11] are given in Table 1 for μQ = 0.412, Q = 30 °C, μP = 0.362, P = 15 kN/m2, μV = 0.361, V = 2 m/s, and μ0 = 0.345.
The vehicle dynamic equation can be written

where δ is the conversion coefficient of the rotating mass, m is the gross vehicle mass, a is the acceleration, Ft is the driving force, Ff is the road friction, Fw is the wind resistance, and Fi is the ramp resistance. Ft, Ff, and Fw are given as

sec.title: 3 Simulation of the Accelerator Pedal Opening
sec.p: The acceleration reflects the driver’s starting intentions when driving on a planar straight road. The driver can change the accelerator pedal only to control the acceleration. Then, the pedal opening curve is taken as the input of the dynamic driveline model after the clutch is synchronized and before the second gear linked together. This is approximated by a cubic polynomial, as shown in Fig. 3.
The pedal opening curve can be expressed as

where c1, c2, c3, and c4 are constants to be determined and t is time. By substituting

sec.title: 4 Orthogonal Design and Analysis
sec.p: The vehicle driveline system considered in this specific case is equipped with an AMT that is used as a launch device. This is depicted schematically in Fig. 4. The dynamic model of the driveline system is built by the simulation tool MATLAB/Simulink.

caption.p: Schematic overview of the vehicle driveline system

sec.p:
The conditions of the acceleration are studied by orthogonal design. The effects of the pedal opening factors (namely the pedal opening
α
, the first derivative
α
·
of the pedal opening, and the second derivative
α
··
of the pedal opening) on the starting intentions are evaluated. The orthogonal design chosen on the basis of experiments avoids the study of all the possible combinations. It has the advantages of studying the effects of multi-factorial variates as well as their interactions in the same experiment. Furthermore, as in orthogonal protocols, evaluation of the effects of various treatments and their interactions are not biased, which results in a better interpretation of the data. As a consequence, this design has the advantage of selecting the optimal protocol conditions.
The range analysis of the orthogonal design for L25(56) is shown in Table 3, in which 25 treatment combinations and six factors, each at the five levels shown in Table 4, are described.

caption.p: Range analysis of the orthogonal design for L25(56)

sec.title: 5 Modelling and Recognition of the Starting Intentions
sec.p: There are several possible choices for the type of statistical model that is used for characterizing the properties of real-world signals. Examples of such statistical models include Gaussian processes, Poisson processes, Markov processes, and hidden Markov processes. An HMM is a statistical model in which the system being modelled is assumed to be a Markov process with an unobserved state. An HMM can be considered as the simplest dynamic Bayesian network.

In a regular Markov model, the state is directly visible to the observer, and therefore the state transition probabilities are the only parameters. In a hidden Markov model, the state is not directly visible, but the output, which is dependent on the state, is visible. Each state has a probability distribution over the possible output tokens. Therefore the sequence of tokens generated by an HMM gives some information about the sequence of states. Note that the adjective ‘hidden’ refers to the state sequence through which the model passes and not to the parameters of the model; even if the model parameters are known exactly, the model is still hidden.

HMMs are especially known for their application in temporal pattern recognition such as speech, handwriting, gesture recognition, part-of-speech tagging, musical score following, partial discharges, and bioinformatics.
A basic HMM is shown in Fig. 5. A typical HMM structure can be expressed as
where N is the number of states, M is the number of observations, πν are the initial state probabilities, Aν are the state transition matrix elements, and Bν are the confusion matrix elements.

Once a system can be described as a HMM, three problems can be solved. The first two are pattern recognition problems: finding the probability of an observed sequence given an HMM (evaluation); finding the sequence of hidden states that most probably generated an observed sequence (decoding). The third problem is generating an HMM given a sequence of observations (learning). The forward or backward algorithm, the Viterbi algorithm, and the Baum–Welch method are used to solve the evaluation, decoding, and learning problem.

According to the pedal opening
α
, the first derivative
α

A typical pedal opening curve is shown in Fig. 6 for fast starting. The experimental data on

caption.p: Typical pedal opening curve within 2 s for fast starting

sec.p:
Although the continuous-density HMM appear to be a promising tool for characterizing the set of the signals, it is expensive in terms of computing time and resources, which is a weakness of the system that renders it unsuitable for real-time implementations of the algorithm on a microprocessor. In order to be in a form suitable for a discrete-density HMM, the set of the signals must be quantized via codebooks, etc. The quantization process requires that a decision be made on the number of discrete symbols allowed for each signal. The experimental data on

The signals are quantized and represented as time sequences consisting of three, three, and two symbols respectively; they are then mixed together to form a time sequence consisting of 18 symbols, which is used for the observable output of the HMMs. Using these data, the HMM model for each type of starting intentions is built. The 20 sets of data for approximately 2 s are used for each model. The Baum–Welch method is used to adjust the model parameters to maximize the probability of the observation sequence given the model. Random initial estimates of the HMM parameters are chosen so that the maximum is the global maximum.

In order to recognize the driver’s starting intentions, a feature analysis of the set of the signals was carried out by calculation of the model likelihoods for the models of slow starting, medium-speed starting, and fast starting. The probability computation is performed using the Viterbi algorithm. Figure 7 shows the recognition progress of a set of data for an unknown model. As can be seen, the log-probabilities for the three models are almost the same when the track length is short. Then the log-probability for the slow-starting model becomes gradually greater than those for the other two models when the track length increases. Therefore the recognition result is the model of slow starting. This can be obtained when the track length is 6, which means that the starting time is 0.6 s.

caption.p: Recognition progress of a set of data

sec.p: Figures 8(a) and (b) show the log-probabilities of ten sets of data for fast starting compared with those for slow starting and medium-speed starting, Figs 8(c) and (d) show the log-probabilities of data for slow starting compared with those for fast starting and medium-speed starting, and Figs 8(e) and (f) show the log-probabilities of data for medium-speed starting compared with those for fast starting and slow starting. The notation λ1, λ2, and λ3 indicates the complete parameter set of the models for fast starting, slow starting, and medium-speed starting respectively. As can be seen, the system is able to recognize the driver’s starting intentions accurately.

caption.p: Comparison of the log-probabilities for slow starting, medium-speed starting, and fast starting: (a), (b) the driver starts with fast starting; (c), (d) the driver starts with slow starting; (e), (f) the driver starts with medium-speed starting

sec.p: Figures 9, 10, and 11 show the mean accuracy as a function of the starting time for fast starting, slow starting, and medium-speed starting respectively. As can be seen, the mean accuracy of the system is increased with increasing starting time, but the mean accuracies for the three models are different at the same starting time. For example, the mean accuracy is approximately 80 per cent when the starting times are 1.6 s, 1.2 s, and 1.7 s for the models with fast starting, slow starting, and medium-speed starting respectively.

caption.p: The mean accuracy as a function of the starting time for fast starting
The mean accuracy as a function of the starting time for slow starting
The mean accuracy as a function of the starting time for medium-speed starting

sec.title: 6 Concluding Remarks
sec.p:
A driver kinesthetically senses the acceleration but not the speed. When starting on a planar straight road, a driver in the experimental car equipped with an AMT can change the accelerator pedal only to control the acceleration. Thus the acceleration reflects the driver’s starting intentions. Based on the simulation results of the dynamic model of the driveline system, the sequences of factors mainly influencing the starting intentions are
α
,
α
·
, and
α
··
, in which
α
has a significant effect on the starting intentions.
α
·
and
α
··
have some effects. The effects of the interactions of
α
,
α
·
, and
α
··
can be ignored. Thus
α
,
α
·
, and
α
··
are taken as the three main parameters to model and recognize the starting intentions by the HMM. The mean accuracy for each model is obtained, and the system is able to recognize the driver’s starting intentions accurately.

All the discussion above is focused on the driver’s starting intentions on a planar straight road. In order to detect the starting intentions on a non-planar straight road such as a sloping road, the extended process is as follows. First, the starting intentions on a sloping road are divided into three models, namely slow starting, medium-speed starting, and fast starting. Three kinds of data respectively for each model are collected. Second, each kind of data is used to train the original trained models on a planar straight road by the Baum–Welch method. Then new extended models can be obtained for both situations including on a planar straight road and on a sloping road. Finally, the extended models can be used to recognize unknown sets of data. In the same way, other situations on a non-planar straight road can be added. Thus the recognition process is universal and extendable.
